data.sampled: This is commonly known as a "collar" strategy. The two put options and two call options form a range, or collar, around the stock price, limiting both the upside and downside potential. The investor receives a premium for selling the put and call options, reducing the cost basis of their underlying position. The net cost of the collar is the difference between the premiums received and paid.

prompt.content: You are a derivatives investor.

Assume all contracts are for 100 shares. Answer with no explanation, only a classification. Given the expiration dates are the same, what is the name of the option strategy being implemented in the following? Sell 1 $150 strike price put at $1.89. Buy 1 $155 strike price put at $2.63. Sell 1 $210 strike price call at $1.85. Buy 1 $205 strike price call at $2.61.

data.sampled:
This is a bear call spread and a bull put spread.

The bear call spread involves selling one higher-strike call option and buying one lower-strike call option with the same expiration date, typically for a net credit. The maximum profit is the net credit received, and the maximum risk is the difference between the two strike prices minus the net credit, which is the width of the spread.

The bull put spread involves selling one lower-strike put option and buying one higher-strike put option with the same expiration date, typically for a net credit. The maximum profit is the net credit received, and the maximum risk is the difference between the two strike prices minus the net credit, which is the width of the spread.

In this case, the investor is receiving a net credit for both spreads, indicating a bullish outlook on the underlying stock. The higher-strike put options sold in the bear call spread provide downside protection, while the lower-strike put options bought in the bull put spread generate income. However, the potential profits are limited, as the maximum possible gain is the net credit received.

data.sampled: An increase in stock price would result in a positive return on this derivatives position. If the stock price increases, the short call will become ITM, resulting in a loss, but the premiums collected from the put sales will exceed the loss on the short call, resulting in a net gain on the position. Therefore, an increase in stock price is optimal for maximizing returns on this position.

data.sampled:
Decrease.

When the stock price decreases, the $125 put will be exercised and the $130 put will expire worthless. At the same time, the $175 call will expire worthless, while the $170 call will be exercised. The net result is that you will get to keep the $130 put premium of $0.23 per share, plus the $0.05 per share received for the call, for a total profit of $0.28 per share.

data.sampled:
The stock price increasing would increase the value of the position as it is currently constructed.

A higher stock price would increase the likelihood of the $38 put being out-of-the-money, which would result in keeping the entire $0.85 premium. The $51 call would also have a decreased likelihood of being in-the-money resulting in keeping the entire $0.15 premium. Lastly, the net credit received for the spread would increase resulting in more cash received for opening the position.

If the stock price increases, all four of the options in the spread would be expected to decrease in value.

prompt.content: You are a derivatives investor.

Assume all contracts are for 100 shares. Answer with no explanation, only a classification. Given the expiration dates are the same, what is the name of the option strategy being implemented in the following? Sell 1 $88 strike price put at $1.49. Buy 1 $93 strike price put at $2.77. Sell 1 $110 strike price call at $1.02. Buy 1 $105 strike price call at $2.06.

data.sampled:
This is a "bear call spread" options strategy. It involves selling one call option and buying another call option with a higher strike price, both with the same expiration date. The $51 strike price call option sold generates income, while the $48 strike price call option bought limits the potential upside gain.

Overall, the strategy has a net credit, which is the difference between the premium received from selling the call option and the premium paid for buying the call option. This net credit is the maximum potential profit the investor can achieve with this strategy. The downside risk is limited to the initial net credit received, plus any additional premiums paid to close the position if the stock price rises above the strike price of the short call option.
